Using fredr

Sam Boysel

2018-07-16

Source: vignettes/fredr.Rmd
fredr.Rmd

Introduction

fredr interacts with the Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED) RESTful API, provided by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. Essentially a simple wrapper of httr and the FRED API itself, fredr is designed with simplicity and flexibility in mind. The core functions are

  • fredr_set_key() - Set the required FRED API key for the session.
  • fredr_series_observations() - Fetch a FRED series.
  • fredr_series_search_text() - Search for a FRED series by text.
  • fredr() - Send a general request to the FRED API.

Objects are returned as tibbles. The user is strongly encouraged to read the full FRED API documentation to leverage the full power of fredr and the FRED API.

Installation

Currently, fredr is only available from GithHub. You can install using devtools::install_github:

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("sboysel/fredr")

Load package

library(fredr)

Authentication

To use fredr and the FRED API in general, you must first obtain a FRED API key. It is also recommended to reveiw the FRED API Terms of Use. Once you’ve obtained an API key, you can set the key as an environment variable using fredr_set_key

fredr_set_key("abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456")

where “abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456” is replaced with the actual key you obtain from FRED. This will set the key for the current session. You can persistently set the key by appending the line FRED_API_KEY=abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456 to an .Renviron file in the working directory. This can be done using a text editor or by running usethis::edit_r_environ. If you edit the .Renviron file, remember to either restart the session or run readRenviron(".Renviron") for the changes to take effect.

Series

Retrieve series

fredr_series_observations retrieves series observations (i.e. the actual time series data) for a specified FRED series ID. The function returns a tibble with 2 columns (observation date and value).

fredr_series_observations(
  series_id = "UNRATE",
  observation_start = as.Date("1990-01-01")
)
#> # A tibble: 342 x 2
#>    date       UNRATE
#>    <date>      <dbl>
#>  1 1990-01-01    5.4
#>  2 1990-02-01    5.3
#>  3 1990-03-01    5.2
#>  4 1990-04-01    5.4
#>  5 1990-05-01    5.4
#>  6 1990-06-01    5.2
#>  7 1990-07-01    5.5
#>  8 1990-08-01    5.7
#>  9 1990-09-01    5.9
#> 10 1990-10-01    5.9
#> # ... with 332 more rows

Leverage the native features of the FRED API by passing additional parameters:

fredr_series_observations(
  series_id = "UNRATE",
  observation_start = as.Date("1990-01-01"),
  frequency = "q",
  units = "chg"
)
#> # A tibble: 114 x 2
#>    date        UNRATE
#>    <date>       <dbl>
#>  1 1990-01-01 -0.0667
#>  2 1990-04-01  0.0333
#>  3 1990-07-01  0.367 
#>  4 1990-10-01  0.433 
#>  5 1991-01-01  0.467 
#>  6 1991-04-01  0.233 
#>  7 1991-07-01  0.0333
#>  8 1991-10-01  0.233 
#>  9 1992-01-01  0.267 
#> 10 1992-04-01  0.233 
#> # ... with 104 more rows

fredr plays nicely with the tidyverse:

library(tidyverse)
fredr_series_search_text(
  search_text = "federal funds",
  order_by = "popularity",
  sort_order = "desc",
  limit = 1) %>%
  pull(id) %>%
  fredr_series_observations(series_id = .) %>%
  ggplot(data = ., mapping = aes(x = date, y = FEDFUNDS)) +
    geom_line()

It is relatively straightforward to convert tibbles returned by fredr into other time series objects. For example,

library(xts)
gnpca <- fredr_series_observations(series_id = "GNPCA", units = "log") %>%
  mutate(GNPCA = GNPCA - lag(GNPCA)) %>%
  filter(!is.na(GNPCA))

gnpca_xts <- xts::xts(
  x = gnpca$GNPCA,
  order.by = gnpca$date
)

gnpca_xts %>%
  StructTS() %>%
  residuals() %>%
  acf(., main = "ACF for First Differenced real US GNP, log")

Search for a series

Search for FRED series.

  • Use fredr_search to search for a series by text in the series description

    fredr_series_search_text("unemployment", limit = 100L)
#> # A tibble: 100 x 16
#>    id        realtime_start realtime_end title            observation_sta…
#>  * <chr>     <chr>          <chr>        <chr>            <chr>           
#>  1 UNRATE    2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Civilian Unempl… 1948-01-01      
#>  2 UNRATENSA 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Civilian Unempl… 1948-01-01      
#>  3 NROU      2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Natural Rate of… 1949-01-01      
#>  4 UNEMPLOY  2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Unemployment Le… 1948-01-01      
#>  5 M0892AUS… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Unemployment Ra… 1929-04-01      
#>  6 Q0892BUS… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Unemployment Ra… 1940-04-01      
#>  7 LNS14000… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Unemployment Ra… 1948-01-01      
#>  8 M0892BUS… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Unemployment Ra… 1940-01-01      
#>  9 M0892CUS… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Unemployment Ra… 1947-01-01      
#> 10 LNU04000… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Unemployment Ra… 1948-01-01      
#> # ... with 90 more rows, and 11 more variables: observation_end <chr>,
#> #   frequency <chr>, frequency_short <chr>, units <chr>,
#> #   units_short <chr>, seasonal_adjustment <chr>,
#> #   seasonal_adjustment_short <chr>, last_updated <chr>, popularity <int>,
#> #   group_popularity <int>, notes <chr>

  • Use fredr_search_id to search for a series by the ID of the series

    fredr_series_search_id("UNRATE", limit = 100L)
#> # A tibble: 16 x 16
#>    id     realtime_start realtime_end title               observation_sta…
#>  * <chr>  <chr>          <chr>        <chr>               <chr>           
#>  1 UNRATE 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Civilian Unemploym… 1948-01-01      
#>  2 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   FOMC Summary of Ec… 2018-01-01      
#>  3 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Longer Run FOMC Su… 2009-02-18      
#>  4 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   FOMC Summary of Ec… 2018-01-01      
#>  5 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Longer Run FOMC Su… 2009-02-18      
#>  6 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   FOMC Summary of Ec… 2018-01-01      
#>  7 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Longer Run FOMC Su… 2009-02-18      
#>  8 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   FOMC Summary of Ec… 2018-01-01      
#>  9 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Longer Run FOMC Su… 2015-06-17      
#> 10 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Civilian Unemploym… 1948-01-01      
#> 11 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   FOMC Summary of Ec… 2018-01-01      
#> 12 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Longer Run FOMC Su… 2009-02-18      
#> 13 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   FOMC Summary of Ec… 2018-01-01      
#> 14 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Longer Run FOMC Su… 2009-02-18      
#> 15 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   FOMC Summary of Ec… 2018-01-01      
#> 16 UNRAT… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Longer Run FOMC Su… 2009-02-18      
#> # ... with 11 more variables: observation_end <chr>, frequency <chr>,
#> #   frequency_short <chr>, units <chr>, units_short <chr>,
#> #   seasonal_adjustment <chr>, seasonal_adjustment_short <chr>,
#> #   last_updated <chr>, popularity <int>, group_popularity <int>,
#> #   notes <chr>

  • Use fredr_search_tags to search for series tags

    fredr_series_search_tags("unemployment", limit = 100L)
#> # A tibble: 100 x 6
#>    name        group_id notes created              popularity series_count
#>  * <chr>       <chr>    <chr> <chr>                     <int>        <int>
#>  1 1-month     gen      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         40            1
#>  2 3-month     gen      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         54            1
#>  3 5-year      gen      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         44            1
#>  4 afghanistan geo      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         21            1
#>  5 albania     geo      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         17            1
#>  6 algeria     geo      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         21            1
#>  7 all items   gen      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         59            1
#>  8 angola      geo      ""    2012-08-29 14:33:53…         19            1
#>  9 arab world  geo      ""    2016-06-15 09:56:27…        -10            1
#> 10 argentina   geo      ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19…         41            1
#> # ... with 90 more rows

  • Use fredr_search_rel_tags to search for series tags related to a given tag. For example, to search for tags related to the tag “usa” in which the series text matches “gnp”, use the following:

    fredr_series_search_related_tags("gnp", "usa", limit = 30L)
#> # A tibble: 30 x 6
#>    name        group_id notes        created       popularity series_count
#>  * <chr>       <chr>    <chr>        <chr>              <int>        <int>
#>  1 capital     gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         58            1
#>  2 consumption gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         62            1
#>  3 corporate   gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         64            1
#>  4 federal     gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         60            1
#>  5 fixed       gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         53            1
#>  6 foreign     gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         44            1
#>  7 gni         gen      Gross Natio… 2013-03-27 0…         49            1
#>  8 government  gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         67            1
#>  9 inflation   gen      ""           2012-06-08 1…         75            1
#> 10 investment  gen      ""           2012-02-27 1…         57            1
#> # ... with 20 more rows

See help(fredr_search) for more details.

Tags

Series tags can be listed or searched for using fredr_tags. For tags matched by the specific request, returned objects will include information such as tag description, popularity, and the number of associated series. The following examples show how to use the various parameters of fredr_tags to

  • To list all tags, run fredr_tags without any parameters (note that the parameter limit defaults to 1000)

    fredr_tags()
#> # A tibble: 1,000 x 6
#>    name                 group_id notes    created  popularity series_count
#>  * <chr>                <chr>    <chr>    <chr>         <int>        <int>
#>  1 nsa                  seas     Not Sea… 2012-02…        100       448104
#>  2 usa                  geo      United … 2012-02…         99       368894
#>  3 annual               freq     ""       2012-02…         92       325473
#>  4 county               geot     County … 2012-02…         77       181325
#>  5 census               src      Census   2012-02…         79       179590
#>  6 nation               geot     ""       2012-02…        100       174523
#>  7 bls                  src      Bureau … 2012-02…         85       113265
#>  8 monthly              freq     ""       2012-02…         92       100536
#>  9 employment           gen      ""       2012-02…         68        93212
#> 10 prosperity scorecard gen      ""       2017-01…         76        87532
#> # ... with 990 more rows

  • Return specific tags by tag name. You can specify multiple tags in a single string by delimiting with a semicolon:

    fredr_tags(tag_names = "gdp;oecd")
#> # A tibble: 2 x 6
#>   name  group_id notes                created      popularity series_count
#> * <chr> <chr>    <chr>                <chr>             <int>        <int>
#> 1 oecd  src      Org. for Economic C… 2012-02-27 …         78        61500
#> 2 gdp   gen      Gross Domestic Prod… 2012-02-27 …         83        48660

  • Return tags for a given group ID

    fredr_tags(tag_group_id = "geo", limit = 50L)
#> # A tibble: 50 x 6
#>    name  group_id notes                    created popularity series_count
#>  * <chr> <chr>    <chr>                    <chr>        <int>        <int>
#>  1 usa   geo      United States of America 2012-0…         99       368894
#>  2 tx    geo      Texas                    2012-0…         56        22055
#>  3 ga    geo      Georgia (U.S. state)     2012-0…         49        12150
#>  4 ca    geo      California               2012-0…         60        11969
#>  5 va    geo      Virginia                 2012-0…         46        10421
#>  6 il    geo      Illinois                 2012-0…         50         9927
#>  7 ky    geo      Kentucky                 2012-0…         47         9514
#>  8 mo    geo      Missouri                 2012-0…         48         9433
#>  9 nc    geo      North Carolina           2012-0…         48         9254
#> 10 in    geo      Indiana                  2012-0…         45         9148
#> # ... with 40 more rows

  • Search for tags by text

    fredr_tags(search_text = "unemployment")
#> # A tibble: 2 x 6
#>   name         group_id notes           created    popularity series_count
#> * <chr>        <chr>    <chr>           <chr>           <int>        <int>
#> 1 unemployment gen      ""              2012-02-2…         75        23892
#> 2 nairu        gen      Non-Accelerati… 2012-08-1…         17            2

View FRED API documentation

To get the most out of the native features of the FRED API, it is highly recommended to review the API endpoint documentation. Within an R session, you can quickly access the web documentation for any endpoint with the convenience function fredr_docs. The following example will open a web browser to the FRED API documentation page on series/observation endpoint.

fredr_docs(endpoint = "series/observations")

You may also use the params option for fredr_docs to go straight to the endpoint’s Parameters section.

fredr_docs(endpoint = "category/related_tags", params = TRUE)

fredr is packaged with a list of possible endpoints in the data frame fredr_endpoints

fredr_endpoints
#> # A tibble: 31 x 3
#>    endpoint                   type       note                             
#>    <chr>                      <chr>      <chr>                            
#>  1 fred/category              Categories Get a category                   
#>  2 fred/category/children     Categories Get the child categories for a s…
#>  3 fred/category/related      Categories Get the related categories for a…
#>  4 fred/category/series       Categories Get the series in a category     
#>  5 fred/category/tags         Categories Get the tags for a category      
#>  6 fred/category/related_tags Categories Get the related tags for a categ…
#>  7 fred/releases              Releases   Get all releases of economic data
#>  8 fred/releases/dates        Releases   Get release dates for all releas…
#>  9 fred/release               Releases   Get a release of economic data   
#> 10 fred/release/dates         Releases   Get release dates for a release …
#> # ... with 21 more rows

General queries

You can also use the low-level function fredr to run more general queries against any FRED API endpoint (e.g. Categories, Series, Sources, Releases, Tags). This is also useful to run complex queries or .

fredr(endpoint = "tags/series", tag_names = "population;south africa")
#> # A tibble: 59 x 16
#>    id       realtime_start realtime_end title             observation_sta…
#>  * <chr>    <chr>          <chr>        <chr>             <chr>           
#>  1 LFWA24T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  2 LFWA24T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  3 LFWA24T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  4 LFWA24T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  5 LFWA25T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  6 LFWA25T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  7 LFWA25T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  8 LFWA25T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#>  9 LFWA55T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#> 10 LFWA55T… 2018-07-16     2018-07-16   Working Age Popu… 2008-01-01      
#> # ... with 49 more rows, and 11 more variables: observation_end <chr>,
#> #   frequency <chr>, frequency_short <chr>, units <chr>,
#> #   units_short <chr>, seasonal_adjustment <chr>,
#> #   seasonal_adjustment_short <chr>, last_updated <chr>, popularity <int>,
#> #   group_popularity <int>, notes <chr>

By default, fredr (and therefore all fredr_* functions) return a tibble. Set to_frame to FALSE to return a generic response object from a httr::GET request that can be further parsed with httr::content

library(httr)
resp <- fredr::fredr(endpoint = "series/observations", series_id = "UNRATE", to_frame = FALSE)
resp
#> Response [https://api.stlouisfed.org/fred/series/observations?series_id=UNRATE&api_key=d3ef3490ef7270cf903d07141e9e7db7&file_type=json]
#>   Date: 2018-07-16 05:35
#>   Status: 200
#>   Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
#>   Size: 79.8 kB
